etymology.description: Pictogram of wheat: middle line = ear, upward lines = leaves, downward lines = stem/roots; sometimes an extra top line. Borrowed early to mean “to come”; later additions like 止/辵 were not retained.
etymology.interpretation: Originally drew a stalk of wheat, with the central stroke as the ear and other strokes as leaves, stem, and roots. It was borrowed early to write “to come,” while 麥 later carried the grain meaning; their similar Old Chinese onsets likely facilitated the semantic shift.
etymology.simplification: Simplified to 来 by reducing and regularizing strokes, following common clerical/cursive forms to lower stroke count and ease writing.

examples.chinese: 请你早点来(請你早點來)。
他今天从上海来开会(他今天從上海來開會)。
examples.pinyin: Tā jīntiān cóng Shànghǎi lái kāihuì.
examples.english: He came from Shanghai to attend a meeting.

examples.chinese: 如果你有时间，明天再来我们家坐坐(如果你有時間，明天再來我們家坐坐)。
examples.pinyin: Rúguǒ nǐ yǒu shíjiān, míngtiān zài lái wǒmen jiā zuòzuo.
examples.english: If you have time, come to our place again tomorrow for a visit.
